I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the Government of 
Cambodia in developing and implementing a one-stop shop model for service delivery using a 
digital platform that is integrated with other pertinent information systems, such as the national 
identification (ID) system.1 The TA will help improve the government’s efficiency and effectiveness 
in  delivering  social  assistance  programs  by  mainstreaming  digital  technology  in  public 
administration. The TA will support operational priority 1 (addressing remaining poverty and 
reducing  inequality)  and  operational  priority  6  (strengthening  governance  and  institutional 
capacity) of Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).2 The TA will also support 
ADB’s  Social  Protection  Operational  Plan  2014−2020,  which  recognizes  information  and 
communication technology (ICT) as a potential sector for investment and knowledge work to 
strengthen  social  protection  programs  in  ADB’s  developing  member  countries.3 It  is  also 
emphasized  in  the  country  partnership  strategy  2019–2023,  and  confirmed  in  the  country 
operations business plan for 2021–2023.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Vulnerabilities. During 2014–2019, Cambodia’s gross domestic product grew by an 
annual average of 7.1%.5 The proportion of Cambodians living below the national poverty line fell 
from 47.8% in 2007 to 13.5% in 2014 and was projected to have fallen to 9.5% in 2019.6 However, 
many households remained close to the poverty line and the impacts from the coronavirus 
disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  threaten  to  reverse  this  progress.  ADB  estimates  that 
570,000 workers will lose their jobs because of COVID-19, and that unemployment will increase 
from 0.7% to 4.4% in 2020. Poverty is also expected to increase as a result of reduced wage 
income, lower remittances, and the additional burden imposed by returning migrants.7 About 
562,686 families vulnerable to the impacts of COVID-19 are being supported under a government 
cash-transfer program.8 It is expected that an additional 210,000 individuals will register in the 
IDPoor database by December 2020 due to increasing poverty. 
 
3.  Social protection system. Before the COVID-19 pandemic, the government’s social 
assistance programs covered less than 2.0% of the poorest quintile of the population.9 The 
government introduced a new Social Protection Policy Framework in 2017.10 The IDPoor poverty 
identification mechanism is an important part of this framework. It has been used to identify and register

been implementing various social protection programs and is planning an expansion. However, 
many challenges threaten the delivery of social benefits, including limited coverage, weak targeting 
of beneficiaries, and inefficient management of social protection programs. Another challenge is 
the lack of effective measures to help vulnerable groups cope with shocks such as a pandemic, 
illness, and natural hazards, which undermines the inclusiveness of social and public services. 
 
4.  Digital transformation. The government aims to make Cambodia an ICT-driven upper 
middle-income country by 2030. Several ICT-related policies, such as the ICT Master Plan (2020), 
the Industrial Development Policy 2015–2025, the Law on e-Commerce (2019), and Consumer 
Protection Law (2019) are being implemented.12 The government is also preparing a long-term 
strategy for the digital economy for 2020–2035.13  Key barriers to achieving digital transformation 
in Cambodia are (i) gaps in supporting infrastructure; (ii) weak governance and institutional 
capacity to implement the digital transformation; and (iii) limited awareness and knowledge of, 
and human capacity for, digital technology. 
 
5.  While Cambodia’s potential to improve delivery of social protection programs through 
digital technology is large, it has no universal and easily verifiable identification mechanism that 
every resident could use to access public and social services. To rectify this, the National Social 
Protection Council (NSPC) plans to develop an integrated ICT-based service delivery system in 
support of the various social protection programs. The digitalization is also driven by the need for 
more efficiency in administering the programs, such as minimizing transaction costs and more 
transparency in identifying and managing beneficiaries.  
 
6.  Response to COVID-19. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the development of 
social  protection  programs.  The  government  prepared  a  comprehensive  response  to  the 
pandemic covering health, social protection, and financial and economic recovery. The timely 
verification of beneficiaries in emergency situations such as the COVID-19 pandemic is a key 
challenge and is essential for effective and timely social protection response. Developing a digital 
platform with an integrated social beneficiary database that is linked to each individual’s unique 
identification will be critical for targeting future support and minimizing leakages in emergency aid 
and follow-on programs. The digital platform proposed under the TA, which is integrated with 
other pertinent information systems such as the national ID system, will be a foundation for a 
comprehensive social service delivery mechanism. 
 
7.  E-government for subnational administrations. Improving the delivery of public and 
social services by using digital technologies will require broader strengthening of subnational e-
government systems. Cambodia is implementing a comprehensive decentralization reform, which 
aims to empower subnational administrations (SNAs) and thereby lower the transaction costs of 
social service delivery. However, institutional capacity is still weak. The national government's 
plan to introduce e-government applications to subnational service delivery is as yet hampered 
by the lack of (i) a comprehensive strategy for digital government, (ii) sufficient human and

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA will be aligned with the following impacts: an efficient and financially sustainable 
social protection system built by boosting human development and national economic growth.14  
The TA will have the following outcome: efficiency, effectiveness, and accountability in delivery of 
selected public and social services in target districts improved.15 The TA will have two outputs: 
(i) an integrated digital platform for social protection programs developed and implemented, and 
the capacity of the stakeholder agencies enhanced; and (ii) a feasibility study on a scalable 
subnational e-government model conducted, and the capacity of the target SNAs enhanced.   
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: An integrated digital platform for social protection programs developed 
and implemented, and the capacity of the stakeholder agencies enhanced. The TA will 
develop an integrated digital platform to provide end-to-end social protection programs. The TA 
will analyze and re-engineer the key business processes of existing social protection programs, 
such as registration, identification, and enrollment of beneficiaries; delivery of social services; and 
monitoring. To demonstrate the utility of the digital platform, the TA will assist in applying it to the 
implementation of the health insurance program under the Ministry of Health and to the conditional 
cash transfer program under the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans, and Youth Rehabilitation. 
The application of the digital platform under the TA will cover a limited geographical area. The 
digital platform will be integrated with other relevant IT systems including the national ID system 
for more efficient and effective service delivery. The platform is expected to be further expanded 
to include other social protection programs and to be scaled up through succeeding digitization 
initiatives. The application of the platform under the TA will cover about 10,000 beneficiaries in 
two districts. The districts will be selected at an early stage of TA implementation.16 Under this 
output, the TA will conduct a cost and benefit analysis, provide technical advisory service, and 
carry out capacity development programs for the stakeholder agencies. The team will collaborate 
with ADB’s Social Development Thematic Group with respect to social and gender analysis, 
monitoring, communication, and public outreach. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Feasibility  study  on  a  scalable  subnational  e-government  model 
conducted, and capacity of the target subnational administrations enhanced. The TA will 
support the development of a scalable subnational e-government model by (i) conducting a 
diagnostic  study  for  SNAs  in  selected  provinces, (ii)  preparing  a  scalable  standardized  e-
government model with new business processes and necessary digital technology infrastructure 
for SNAs, (iii) developing an e-government road map, and (iv) preparing detailed implementation 
plans for the scalable standardized e-government model for possible implementation under the

ADB funded project.17 The target government functions to be studied under this output will be 
determined and decided at the early stage of the TA implementation in light of the priority areas

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,100,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  and  administered  by  ADB.18 The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, secretarial support, 
office  supplies,  salary  for  civil  servants,  office  spaces,  communication  facilities,  domestic 
transportation, and other in-kind contributions. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The TA will be administered by ADB. The secretariat of the NSPC, which is chaired by the 
Ministry of Economy and Finance, will be the executing agency. The NSPC will also be the 
implementing agency for output 1 and, to coordinate the TA implementation, it will set up a project 
steering committee (PSC) with representatives of the government agencies concerned, including 
the General Department of National Identification of the Ministry of Interior; the Ministry of Health; 
and the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans, and Youth Rehabilitation. The Secretariat of the 
National Committee for Subnational Democratic Development (NCDD-S) will be the implementing 
agency for output 2.

14.  Consulting services. The TA will require 61 person-months of international consultants 
and 116 person-months of national consultants. Consulting packages will include (i) a firm to 
provide a team of international and national consultants to develop an integrated digital platform 
for social protection programs; (ii) a firm to provide a team of international and national consultants 
to develop a scalable e-government model for SNAs; and (iii) individual consultants to coordinate 
the  TA  implementation.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA;  engage,  supervise,  and  evaluate  the 
consultants; and carry out procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated staff instructions. For both outputs, consulting firms will be 
engaged using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio as 
the  default  selection  method.  Both  international  and  national  individual  consultants  will  be 
recruited  though  the  ADB-managed  consultant  management  system,  wherein  shortlisted 
candidates may be hired as needed to provide the required outputs.19 For the consulting services 
contracts, output-based or lump sum contracts will be considered. The consulting firms will 
procure goods which are provided under their contracts, organize workshops, and provide staff 
to act as resource persons in the workshops, as applicable.
 
15.  Cofinancier requirements. As the TA is funded by JFPR, it will comply with JFPR Policy 
and Guidelines regarding visibility of Japan. The TA will discuss with the local Japanese Embassy 
and JICA Office to identify possibilities for collaboration. Specifically, all press releases, training 
programs, and publications concerning the TA will mention the financial contribution from the 
Government of Japan.  
 
16.  Governance. Both the NSPC and the NCDD-S have good experience in managing ADB-
funded  projects  and  programs,  and  with  ADB  procurement  and  financial  management 
arrangements. Most of the TA funds will be spent on the engagement of consulting services and 
the procurement of digital technology infrastructure, which will be directly managed by ADB. Given 
the high level of governance risk in Cambodia, ADB staff will carry out due diligence on the 
procurement and monitoring of consulting services, and on fund disbursements for capacity 
development activities during TA review missions. In addition, the EA/IAs will receive briefings on 
the status of procurement and disbursements, and on prevention of fraud and corruption. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  
$2,000,000 to the Government of Cambodia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund 
for Poverty Reduction for the Supporting Digital Cambodia for Inclusive Development Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
